title: Oil prices edge lower as China's GDP growth slows
text: Oil prices slipped on Monday after China posted its slowest quarterly economic growth in at least 27 years, reinforcing concerns about demand in the world's largest crude oil importer.

title: China posts its lowest quarterly growth in 27 years as trade war drags on
text: China’s economy grew 6.2% in the second quarter from a year ago, the country’s statistics bureau said on Monday.

title: Investors searching for yield should buy this sector in Singapore, strategists say
text: Real estate investment trusts listed in Singapore — commonly known as S-REITs — have been a favorite among institutional investors this year.

title: Oil prices edge down ahead of expected weak Chinese economic data
text: Oil prices edged down on Monday, dragged down by expectations that China, the world's largest crude oil importer, will post its slowest pace of economic growth in at least 27 years as the trade war between Beijing and Washington bites.

title: Asian shares, dollar brace for China GDP
text: Asian shares started the week on a softer note on Monday after posting their first weekly decline since early June, while the dollar was on the defensive ahead of key economic data from China.

title: U.S. companies may soon get OK to sell to Huawei again: report
text: The Trump administration may start approving certain U.S. companies to sell their products to China's Huawei Technologies Co. in as soon as two weeks.

title: Exclusive: U.S. firms may get nod to restart Huawei sales in 2-4 weeks - official
text: The U.S. may approve licenses for companies to re-start new sales to Huawei in as little as two weeks, according to a senior U.S. official, in a sign President Donald Trump's recent effort to ease restrictions on the Chinese company could move forward quickly.

title: Paul Singer and David Rubenstein Debate the State of the Economy
text: Paul Singer (Trades, Portfolio) of Elliott Management and David Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group sat on stage together at an Aspen Ideas Festival.

title: Wall Street is relying too much on the Fed to extend the record rally, Wilmington Trust warns
text: Wilmington Trust's Meghan Shue says the market is overestimating the Fed's ability to support the economy.

title: U.S. Fed seen launching repo facility in early 2020: Deutsche Bank
text: The Federal Reserve may launch a policy tool to lend to banks using Treasuries and other securities as collateral in early 2020 with possible testing to begin later this year, a Deutsche Bank strategist said.

title: Fighting Big Tech Makes for Some Uncomfortable Bedfellows
text: Conservatives are showing up at largely liberal conferences to call for breaking up Facebook and Google. Liberals are going on conservative TV shows to do the same.

title: The Week Ahead: Are Wall Street Strategists Too Bearish?
text: Historically Wall Street strategists are two bullish as the have filed for many years to uniformly predict a down year for the stock market. Currently the S&P 500 is already above most of their year-end targets so what does it mean if they start raising their targets?

title: US stocks rise to record highs – four experts on what to watch now
text: It was a record-breaking week for U.S. stocks. With second-quarter earnings season approaching, can the optimism continue to hold on?

title: Why Big Tech Stock Buybacks May Be Slowing
text: Heavy buyback action has contributed to outperformance by tech stocks in 2019, but the cash available for future share repurchases is running low.

title: The Case for Private Equity when Stocks Tumble
text: Studies by JPMorgan and Hamilton Lane suggest that investors should consider swapping their holdings of public stocks for private equity right now.

title: Blind Spots in Investing
text: Blind spot (vision), also known as the physiological blind spot, the specific scotoma in the visual field that corresponds to the lack of light-detecting photoreceptor cells on the optic disc.

title: Huawei reportedly plans to lay off hundreds of employees in the US
text: The layoffs are expected to hit Huawei's U.S. development subsidiary Futurewei, according to the Journal.

title: Federal Reserve fixed its own fumble by cutting rates
text: Last week, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell telegraphed to the markets that a rate cut is coming. There seems to be quite a bit of uncertainty over why the Fed would cut rates so shortly after aggressively raising them — eight times since 2016, with the most recent hike just last December.

title: Don’t blame flawed Silicon Valley for the rot of Wall Street and Washington
text: The techlash is well underway. Blame Facebook!

title: Huawei plans extensive layoffs at its U.S. operations: WSJ
text: Huawei Technologies Co Ltd is planning extensive layoffs in the United States as the Chinese telecoms equipment company grapples with its U.S. blacklisting, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.
